Does not exist a formal National Open Data Strategy published yet. Since 2021, a project is underway for the National Data Strategy, (URL: https://portugaldigital.gov.pt/en/accelerating-digital-transition-in-portugal/get-to-know-the-digital-transition-strategies/national-data-strategy/). The document should be finshed until the end of 2022 but to our knowledge that was not accomplished.
Another project coordenated by the AMA (Administrative Modernization Agency) is in execution since August 2022 for the definition if the Data Strategy in the Public Administration (URL: not available); Both projects addresses open data as well. 
Other relevant informations are:
The Recovery and Resilience Plan (PRR) has a mission framework that also defines strategic objectives for open data. (URL: https://recuperarportugal.gov.pt/wp-content/uploads/2021/10/PRR.pdf). In addition to these references, there are others; that are also related to open data: 1 - In regards to public open data, the strategy is embedded in our ICT government strategy, as an enabler of innovation and competitiveness, with measures including: the extension of the open data disclosure and use via the national data portal; the disclosure of execution indicators and benefits accomplished by executing public administration policies, initiatives and projects; and, the provision of instruments that facilitate the participation of citizen in public decision processes. 2 - It is part of the National Strategy for AI to guarantee an ethical-by-design AI, where open data plays a relevant role. Please see URL: https://tic.gov.pt/pt/web/tic/guia .
View "AI strategy" on https://www.incode2030.gov.pt/sites/default/files/julho_incode_brochura.pdf. 3 - It is part of the INCoDE.2030's competencies to elaborate the "National Open Data Strategy" view more on this link https://www.incode2030.gov.pt/sites/default/files/portugal_incode_en_web_single_0.pdf. There is currently a preliminary report. See appendix "preliminary-report". Also within INCoDE.2030 there is a plan on data life cycle management in the Public Administration, which includes an extensive re-qualification of Public Administration agents and a training program for Chief Data Officers. INCoDE.2030 is an integrated public policy initiative dedicated to strengthening digital skills. 4 - The Portuguese simplification programme - SIMPLEX, which acts as a general purpose action plan for the modernization of the public administration, has measures related to open data. https://www.simplex.gov.pt/medidas. 5 - There are strategies for open data portals, sectoral or local, as an example: Lisbon City Council specific strategy http://lisboaaberta.cm-lisboa.pt/index.php/pt/estrategia-de-dados-abertos . 6 - A project is being executed at present time named "Public Administration's Data National Strategy and Action Plan" ("Estratégia Nacional de Dados na AP e respetivo Plano de Ação") in which are included measures for the public administration's open data. Information about this project can be found in the transparency portal, URL: https://www.base.gov.pt/Base4/pt/detalhe/?type=contratos&id=9502376.

By the Law No. 68/2021. Examples: The entities covered must ensure the publication of available documents and data, inventories of accessible documents and related metadata, as well as search possibilities, under the terms of the regime of access to administrative and environmental information and the reuse of administrative documents. The data.gov portal is the central catalog of open data in Portugal, with the function of aggregating, referencing, publishing and hosting open data from different bodies and sectors of Central, Regional and Local Public Administration, also functioning as an indexing portal, of content hosted on other open, sectoral or decentralized data portals or catalogs:
• The open data made available therein must maintain levels of updating and permanent quality, so that they can be reliably reused by other computer applications;
• If the entity producing the open data does not make them accessible from its own systems, it must make them available on the data.gov portal, and must also ensure that they are always updated there. The related metadata must always be made available in an updated form to the data.gov portal, in order to facilitate their search and location as open data, including in cases where the entity producing the open data makes them accessible from of own systems; etc.
The  concrete action/measures planned for the fulfilling of those obligation are laid down in the document "Plano de Ação Transversal para a Transformação Digital da AP 2021-2023"  (https://tic.gov.pt/documentos/plano-de-acao-para-a-transformacao-digital-da-ap-2021-2023), which corresponds to the Action Plan for "Estratégia de Transformação Digital da AP 2021-2023" (https://tic.gov.pt/estrategias/estrategia-2021-2026), Action 2 comprehends several measures relating to the open data filed.

Of common scope to some of the strategies/policies, it is referred: The creation of infrastructures to support the consumption of data in real-time on the open data national portal; The identification of services that produce and optimize the consumption of data in real-time; The increase of real-time datasets on the national open data portal. One of "CTIC TIC 2021-2023-2026 Strategy" key goals is a single, integrated system allowing to enrich operational databases with geolocation, cartographic, socio-economic, populational, meteorological information, and points of interest. Real-time updates with smart business information and analysis tools. CTIC Strategy 21-26:Strategic line II, «Strengthening data»: Public Administration insights from data on the the needs of citizens in relation to public services. // AP needs to harness the full potential of big data it has access to in order to support public services delivery, management and decisions based on reliable data, aiming to develop services based on emerging technologies, transparency and to boost studies and innovative solutions developed by the society and the private sector, in line with the European Data Strategy. // Increase open datasets available with data.gov.pt for reuse and valorization by society.  Strategy for Innovation and Modernization of the State and Public Administration 20-23: Provide citizens and companies with safe, accessible and seamless services, facilitating and reducing interactions, making data available and reusing and promoting efficiency, sustainability and simplification of the AP's operating processes // It is important to train the Public Administration to organize work differently, taking advantage of its data and data science techniques. Furthermore, it is still necessary to generalize the sharing of open data and encourage its use by citizens and companies, which increases transparency and allows for broad collaboration in the identification and satisfaction of needs. // Promote and support the use of the Public Administration interoperability platform for the integration of services and data reuse, including artificial intelligence, quality and data analysis services. // Promotion of the Program in Data Science and Artificial Intelligence in Public Administration through public tenders and calls to support new R&D projects that involve partnerships between Public Administration and scientific institutions.

CTIC Strategy 21-26: Strategic line (2) Strengthening data of the utmost importance for the development of the economy and national productivity — for example, the European Commission estimates that open data will have an impact of around €190 billion in the Gross Domestic Product of European Union countries in 2030.

CTIC Strategy 21-26: It is necessary to catalog, know and manage the data, so that true value can be obtained, ensuring the necessary quality for reuse, namely to not exclude or discriminate fringes of the population, influencing decisions taken, either by human decision makers or artificial intelligence systems. Strategy for Innovation and Modernization of the State and Public Administration 20-23: Measure 10.2 — Create a generic mechanism that allows citizens to be informed of the primary sources of personal data in the Public Administration and to update and manage access authorizations to such data. INCoDE 2030: Within INCoDE.2030 there is a plan on data life cycle management in the Public Administration, which includes an extensive re-qualification of Public Administration agents and a training program for Chief Data Officers. INCoDE.2030 is an integrated public policy initiative dedicated to strengthening digital skills.

CTIC Strategy 21-26: Increase the transparency of the main services and essential areas of the State through the provision of dashboards from the reuse of open data available at data.gov.pt. // Strategy for Innovation and Modernization of the State and Public Administration 20-23, Strategic Objective 10: Manage the data ecosystem with security and transparency. Using data to improve analytics, including ethically supported by artificial intelligence, is essential for informed decision making. For this, it is essential to promote trust when developing secure systems at each stage of the digital transformation, taking into account the maximum requirement of information assurance, that is, the permanent verification of the properties of integrity, availability, authenticity, non-repudiation and confidentiality.

One important action for fighting corruption and increase transparency in the public administrations, is the publication of the reuse of open data sourced via National Data Portal, dados.gov, that is named "+Transparência" (URL: https://transparencia.gov.pt/pt/). This reuse presents several financial aspects of the government, some examples are, european funding and gov budget.

There is a governance structure associated with the CTIC 2021-2023-2026 Strategy, already referred/mentioned before (10c question), where AMA is part of the technical committee. AMA regularly streamlines the relationship with stakeholders to support the availability of datasets on dados.gov. The institution assumes the responsibility of maintaining, managing, and making the national open data portal evolve, as well as boosting the community and ecosystem of open data in Portugal.

A national top-down strategy has not yet been formalized by the central government. Regarding local government, initiatives are developed in a bottom-up logic. Other central entities are free to pursue their own initiatives but generally coordinate voluntarily with AMA, through dados.gov

There are measures to promote contact with the academy, with city councils, associations, NGOs, developers, start ups. Strategies and Portals at local/regional level are part of local/regional policies and decisions, they do not come, formally, as a national policy.

The National open data team manages the national open data portal, dados.gov.pt. This teams works at AMA - Administrative Modernization Agency (https://www.ama.gov.pt/web/english/competences), now under the department "Centro de Competências Digitais da Administração Pública (TicAPP) ". You can consult the organization's organogram in the link https://www.ama.gov.pt/documents/24077/27653/Organograma_AMA_Site_20230201.pdf/2fce90b5-c7a3-4f00-a1d7-e860f8c95ec8 . That organogram is high level and shows the data and interoperability team, in which the open data team is parf of.
In document "Plano de Ação Transversal para a Transformação Digital da AP 2021-2023"  (https://tic.gov.pt/documentos/plano-de-acao-para-a-transformacao-digital-da-ap-2021-2023), page 6, Action 2, is patent the AMA's role as the main responsble for the Action coordination. In the national open data portal, dados.gov (https://dados.gov.pt/pt/contact/), you can check in the footnote that AMA is the site's manager.

The definition is objectively laid down in the national law No. 68/2021 (Article No. 3, g), which transposes the EU directive 1024/2019. URL: https://dre.pt/dre/detalhe/lei/68-2021-170221042  - ""The utilization, by individuals or entities, of administrative documents or data held by the authorities and entities referred to in the following article (Article No. 4- Subjective scope of application), or held on their behalf, for commercial or non-commercial purposes other than the initial purpose for which the documents were produced."".

Answer: Yes, there is a strong focus
Justification: The transposition of the directive 1024/2019, by national law No. 68/2019 (https://dre.pt/dre/detalhe/lei/68-2021-170221042) is an objective instrument that expresses the interest, at the national level, to observe and monitor the extent of re-use of open data, since it has an article (Article No. 10 - Monitorização) in which explicitly defines the monitoring role of a special commission -  CADA. The CADA's monitoring activities are, among others: the monitoirng of the social and economic impact of re-use; the number of re-uses; and the HVD impact. Futhermore, AMA (Agência para a Modernização Administrativa) lunched a public tender and contracted a consultancy to evaluate the impact of open data and its reuse (https://www.base.gov.pt/Base4/pt/detalhe/?type=contratos&id=9601046). The ongoing project called Dados Abertos - Definição de modelo de avaliação de impacto (Open Data - Impact Assessment Model Definition) is, among other things, performig case studies with reusers and open data portals.

The CADA's monitoring activities are (role defined in the national law No. 68/2019 on open data, https://dre.pt/dre/detalhe/lei/68-2021-170221042), among others: the social and economic impact of re-use; the number of re-uses; and the HVD impact.
Futhermore, at the national open data portal, dados.gov, a dashboard updates the number of publications of re-uses and its temporal evolution.
A monitoring improved dashboard is also being designed to be published at the national open data portal (dados.gov), with indicators of entities activity regarding to open data (example: the degree of compliance with the Law regarding High Value Datasets).

In several activities like, webinars, workshops, public presentations, datathons, hackathons, to which public bodies are invited, a direct diologue is established between different stakeholders to promote and incentivate the encourage entities to monitor the re-use of their own published data. A few examples are: the Webinar "Data Strategy in Public Administration" (URL: https://dados.gov.pt/pt/posts/a-ama-dinamizou-um-workshop-sobre-estrategia-de-dados-na-administracao-publica-ap/), "The importance of Open Data" (URL: https://dados.gov.pt/pt/posts/ogw-ii/) and "Open Data" (URL: https://dados.gov.pt/pt/posts/webinar-dados-abertos-1/)
There are also direct contacts with publishers at the national portal to monitor the activity of the portal. This channel is an incentive to the public bodies to monitor this kind of users' activity (in "Atividade da Comunidade" from https://dados.gov.pt/pt/dashboard/).

AMA, the entity that manages the national open data portal, dados.gov, in line with the law No. 68/2021, has an ongoig project in which one of  its main objectives is to implement a framework to monitor the level of re-use of high-value datasets, in coordination with measures to catalogue and promote the re-use of high-value datasets. A special  group/contact points is going to be created within the scope of CTIC 2021-2023-2026 governance, that will be responsible for the high value datasets/re-use in the respective governance area.

According to the Strategy and Studies Unit of the Portuguese Government, the impact "is measured by considering the activities developed to monitor the reuse of data, as well as the results of that reuse." And "the positive impacts range from the creation of value in the economy, the improvement of scientific and technological capacity, to the promotion of transparency, citizen participation and accountability of public bodies." URL: https://www.gee.gov.pt/pt/estudos-e-seminarios/artigos-category/32493-em-analise-dados-abertos-em-portugal

AMA has been implementing the project entitled "Dados Abertos - Definição de modelo de avaliação de impacto" (Open Data- Impact Assessment Model  Definition; URL https://www.base.gov.pt/Base4/pt/detalhe/?type=contratos&id=9601046), funded under the Recovery and Resilience Plan (Consulting and Development for Digital Public Services; Interoperability and Support for Digital Transformation of Public Administration). This project consists of a year-round study aimed at measuring the impact of open data through PA bodies (central, local and regional) utilizing or reusing open datasets. This study has established a survey based on recommendations from official data.europa.eu reports and best practices from EU member states. The already gathered reuse cases will be surveyed using pre-established metrics to quantitatively capture the estimated impact of their data policy, quality, and platform, as well as the created governmental, social, environmental, and economic impact.

The national open government partnerships include 1) government entities, 2) academia, and 3) business associations and civil society. One of the 4 pillars of its first Open Administration National Action Plan (URL: https://ogp.eportugal.gov.pt/monitorizacao) is precisely open data. OGP Portugal aims to guarantee concrete commitments from governments to promote transparency, encourage public participation, fight corruption, and use new technologies to strengthen participatory democracy - https://ogp.eportugal.gov.pt/inicio. 
In December of 2022, in accordance with the pillars of the second Open Administration National Action Plan 2022 (URL: https://ogp.eportugal.gov.pt/ii-panaa), AMA launched the Mosaico platform (URL: https://mosaico.gov.pt/) which promotes universal access to information between the state and the citizen.
Besides OGP, other examples are: 
1) Arquivo.pt, which promotes an annual contest for innovative works carried out based on open data (preserved by Arquivo.pt). Arquivo.pt is developed by the Scientific Computing Unit of FCT - Foundation for Science and Technology - https://sobre.arquivo.pt/pt/conheca-os-vencedores-do-premio-arquivo-pt-2022/. 
2) The Urban Co-Creation Data Lab is a project that aims to provide support on decision making at the city level on high-quality services for citizens. The project is a collaboration between the Portuguese government (AMA) and NOVA IMS University. The project supports new planning and management approaches altogether with new tools to evaluate the impact and predict various services demand (URL: https://www.urbandatalab.pt/). 
3) The DSPA represents the Data Science sector and promotes data science in Portugal and internationally. The association also promotes regulation, ethics, and security in the field of data science. It shares experiences, innovations, case-studies, and success stories and promotes innovation and entrepreneurship of Portuguese companies (URL: https://dspa.pt/)

[Response to reviewer] 
The ongoing project entitled "Open Data - Impact Assessment Model Definition" (URL: https://www.base.gov.pt/Base4/pt/detalhe/?type=contratos&id=9601046) has implemented systematic methods for collecting (re)use cases, incorporating best practices (while also accounting for the cautionary lessons) from reports such as "Rethinking the Impact of Open Data," "The Economic Impact of Open Data," and "The Use Case Observatory Volume I" available on data.europa.eu.
The systematic methods for gathering eligible entities for building use cases about the impact they create when (re)using open data are the following prioritization rules:
a) having ongoing or scheduled data platforms, explicit data policies, data quality control procedures, and/or a general knowledge of its platform users
b) the data platform is in the form of a website, data portal, or web application
c) entities can be classified as private, public (government) or academic institutions
d) entities can maintain regular and effective communication with the Administrative Modernization Agency, I.P. (AMA)
e) entities can underpin if their operational influence is in at least one of the following sectors: social, governmental, environmental or economic
f) entities can be classified into at least one of the following positions of the open data value chain: data reuser, data portal, data intermediary
Upon their acceptance of the collaboration, they were provided with an impact assessment questionnaire.
Reviewer 2 Comments: Please describe what the systematic methods for collecting reuse cases are

Is there any information available on how the reuse cases will be classified/the process that will be used to classify them? In general, we can only consider currently implemented activities/definitions and not planned activities.

Justification:
[Response to reviewer] 
1 - The study "Smart & open cities: Portuguese municipalities open data policies evaluation" (URL: https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/abstract/document/7975912) provides a quantitative overview of the open data landscape in Portuguese cities based on the use of the Local Open Data Census platform (provided by Open Knowledge International - OKI) to evaluate the capacity to implement policies and frames its progress in terms of economic development and innovation, government transparency and citizen engagement impact.
2 - The study "The Open Data policies in Portugal: analysis of its implementation and impact" makes an assessment based on homologous data sources - OKI - and expands its framework to the national level, and applied to the implementation of scientific data and public sector data, including data portals (URL: https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Paulo-Silva-119/publication/322011884_As_Politicas_de_Open_Data_em_Portugal_analise_da_sua_implementacao_e_impacto/links/5a3d6ced0f7e9ba8688e8fbf/As-Politicas-de-Open-Data-em-Portugal-analise-da-sua-implementacao-e-impacto.pdf)
Reviewer 1 Comments: These examples seem to be reuse cases that better fit Q41-Q44. This question is interested in data/studies on the impact created by open data relating to government challenges.

Justification:
1- Publishing data on the dematerialization of medical paper prescriptions by electronic means exemplifies how open data has a substantial impact on the efficiency and effectiveness of a government in delivering public services by reducing administrative burdens, eliminating paper-based processes, enhancing accuracy, facilitating faster access to prescriptions, and enabling seamless coordination among healthcare providers, ultimately resulting in improved healthcare delivery and patient care outcomes (URL: https://transparencia.sns.gov.pt/explore/dataset/desmaterializacao-eletronica-da-receita/table/?sort=periodo).
2- The use of open data on illegal parking (URL: https://urbandatalab.pt/index.php/component/sppagebuilder/?view=page&id=118pen) allows for the identification of patterns and prediction of parking in the city of Lisbon thus improving surveillance efficiency. 
3- The Primary Health Care Identity Card allows for the proper management and efficiency in the use of health resources (URL: https://www.spms.min-saude.pt/2020/07/bi-csp-bilhete-de-identidade-dos-cuidados-de-saude-primarios/)

[Response to reviewer]  
1- The Complementary tool to the Electronic national official journal (https://incm-tst.outsystemsenterprise.com/INOV_DRE/Home) offers open access to legal information and fosters a deeper comprehension of laws and regulations, thereby ensuring transparency in decision-making processes and facilitating accountability by empowering citizens to hold public administrations responsible through enhanced accessibility to legal content; 
2- The More Transparency Portal (URL: https://transparencia.gov.pt/pt/), a barometer of the NextGenerationEU fund application at the national and municipal levels, allowing:
2.1 - citizens to have access to information through a data visualization tool (URL: https://transparencia.gov.pt/pt/fundos-europeus/prr/barometro/ complemented with straightforward channels for downloading the source open data (URL: https://transparencia.gov.pt/pt/fundos-europeus/prr/barometro/ and technical documentation URL: https://transparencia.gov.pt/pt/fundos-europeus/prr/dimensao/resiliencia/) 
2.2 - evaluating how does Portugal compare in the NextGenerationEU fund application to other member states, e.g., URL: https://www.portugal.gov.pt/pt/gc23/comunicacao/noticia?i=portugal-e-dos-paises-mais-avancados-na-execucao-do-prr
3- The Open data and statistics regarding criminality indicators https://partilha.justica.gov.pt/Transparencia/Cadernos-Tematicos/Criminalidade is a tool that allows research journalists to delve deeper into, for example, corruption crimes, allowing long-term assessments of the state of anti-corruption efforts with detailed accounts of the number of investigations, convictions and sentences and, thus, substanciate trends in levels of criminality, severity of penalties, rates of case dismissals, duration of investigation and appropriateness of investigative resource allocation.
Reviewer 2 Comments: The second and third examples of the transparency portal and criminality indicators do not appear to be reuse cases but rather means of making open data more accessible for reuse. Please instead describe ways that open data have been used to create come effect regarding transparency and accountability of public administrations.

Justification:
[Reponse to reviewer]
Examples are:
1- Platform to support the participatory processes of the public administration (URL: https://participa.gov.pt/base/about) enables citizens and stakeholders to actively engage in policy discussions and thus, by providing a means for collaboration, gathering input, and incorporating diverse perspectives, the platform promotes policy-making processes, including problem identification and policy formulation; 
2- The Competition Authority has implemented an internal procedure for assessing the competitive impact of public policies by analyzing existing legislation and regulation data in selected sectors and proposed pro-competitive changes URL: https://www.compete2020.gov.pt/noticias/detalhe/Proj12272IMPACT2020. The resulting Competition Assessment Project can be accessed in URL: https://www.oecd.org/daf/competition/portugal-competition-assessment-project.htm
3- The More Transparency Portal (URL: https://transparencia.gov.pt/pt/), a barometer of the NextGenerationEU fund application at the national and municipal levels, allowing:
3.1 - citizens to have access to information through a data visualization tool (URL: https://transparencia.gov.pt/pt/fundos-europeus/prr/barometro/ complemented with straightforward channels for downloading the source open data (URL: https://transparencia.gov.pt/pt/fundos-europeus/prr/barometro/ and technical documentation URL: https://transparencia.gov.pt/pt/fundos-europeus/prr/dimensao/resiliencia/) 
3.2 - evaluating how does Portugal compare in the NextGenerationEU fund application to other member states, e.g., URL: https://www.portugal.gov.pt/pt/gc23/comunicacao/noticia?i=portugal-e-dos-paises-mais-avancados-na-execucao-do-prr
Reviewer 2 Comments: Please describe the role of open data in these examples

Justification:
1- The Strategic Global Plan for Rationalization and Cost Reduction in Public Administration (PGETIC) aims at, through Information and Communication Technologies, improving the efficiency of the internal processes of the Public Administration and improve the quality of services provided to Citizens and Companies (URL: https://pgetic.tic.gov.pt/ticgov/pgetic); 
2- In the EU project UCD Lab (Grant Agreement - INES / CEF / ICT / A2018 / 1837945, Action 2018 - EU - IA – 0099), in which AMA is a partner, several applications with open data were developed for the efficiency and effectiveness improvement of public services at the municipality level. Predictive model of micro mobility. Besides the predicted commute pattern, the model results will be also useful for micro mobility vehicles operation, improving effectiveness. URL:https://urbandatalab.pt/index.php/component/sppagebuilder/?view=page&id=116

[Response to reviewer]
The following study used a focus group to test what is the impact digital tools, operating with various data sources, including open data, are having on societal chalenges, especially smart cities, and concluded that portuguese parishes will become smarter by the implementation of ongoing innovation accelerators URL: https://run.unl.pt/bitstream/10362/110862/1/Innovation_accelerator_to_make_Portuguese_smarter.pdf
Reviewer 1 Comments: These examples seem to be reuse cases that better fit Q46-Q49. This question is interested in data/studies on the impact created by open data relating to social challenges.

Justification:
[Response to reviewer]
 The "Migra Play" is a platform that dynamically shows the evolution of statistical data on immigrants in Portugal URL: https://www.om.acm.gov.pt/migra-play. It displays in an animated and interactive way data of annual reports on: migrants and their political rights including woman, asilum seekers and religious minorities; the reports and the source data can be downloaded from the main website.
Reviewer 2 Comments: The current descirption seems to refer to relevant datasets and not reuse cases that put open data to use to have an effect. Please instead describe reuse cases.

Justification:
[Response to reviewer]
Examples of iniciatives having an impact on the society's level of awareness concerning housing in urban areas:
1- The "Arrendamento Acessível" platform uses government's datasets on social housing and house rent support (e.g., https://dados.gov.pt/pt/datasets/edificios-de-habitacao-social-n-o/ https://dados.gov.pt/pt/datasets/candidaturas-a-programas-municipais-de-acesso-a-habitacao-e-de-apoio-ao-arrendamento/) to improve market offer gaps of affordable houses for families with different levels of household income https://www.portaldahabitacao.pt/web/guest/arrendamento-acessivel 
2 - Space for knowledge and information sharing on urban policies and analytical tools for urban development - https://www.forumdascidades.pt/forum; 
3 - Scientific publications on the topic of open address data (https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/17445647.2022.2114862) facilitate the comparison of census-based estimates of population distribution with more direct evidence. This expedites the reuse of variables, such as the number of buildings and accommodations per person or age group, for conducting comprehensive analyses on the state of housing conditions in the Portuguese territory.
Reviewer 2 Comments: Please elaborate further on these examples: what is the role of open data and what does the reuse case achieve/what is its impact?

Justification:
[Response to reviewer]
Examples include:
1- The "Resposta Sazonal em Saúde" (Seasonal Health Response) is a platform with interactive dashboards of the daily updates on the progression, accessibility, and use of healthcare services by citizens, namely primary Healthcare, hospital healthcare, and emergency healthcare. It provides timely information to the populace and healthcare sector stakeholders, facilitating their effective preparedness for response https://www.sns.gov.pt/plano-de-contingencia-sazonal/
2- The Daily Evolution of Emergency Calls seeks to inform the public on health initiatives, resource allocation, and the development of preventive measures.URL: https://transparencia.sns.gov.pt/explore/dataset/acionamentos-de-meios-de-emergencia-medica/table/?sort=periodo
In particular, it allows to monitor the response times relative to the number of daily emergency events and determine the nation-wide average response time as well as allow nation-wide media outlets to create awareness on the public to sub-optimal response times https://expresso.pt/sociedade/2022-10-23-INEM-demorou-uma-hora-ou-mais-a-acionar-meios-em-mais-de-mil-chamadas-d36ee608 
3 - The "Centro de Saúde Fora de Horas" (After-hours Healthcare Centers, URL: https://www.arslvt.min-saude.pt/centros-de-saude-fora-de-horas/#14) is a data visualization map of healthcare centers with extended working hours. Its primary goal is to reduce the demand for hospital emergency services among patients who, while experiencing an acute illness, do not require such specialized care. This tool has been featured in national-level media outlets, e.g., https://www.publico.pt/2022/11/23/sociedade/noticia/portal-sns-passa-informacao-centros-saude-abertos-ate-tarde-2028846
Reviewer 2 Comments: The first example seems to be a relevant dataset and not a reuse case. For the second example, please describe the role of open data and the impact created by the project.

Justification:
[Response to Reviewer]
1- The data intermediary PORDATA provides indicators on education in Portugal, namely on education-related expenses, the population's education level, and the level of social action through awarded scholarships. URL: https://www.pordata.pt/tema/portugal/educacao-17
2- An open archive of documents on education and science budget forecasts, global policy implementation assessment, and education system functioning. URL:https://www.igefe.mec.pt/Documentos
3- Re-use of open data to provide extensive indicators on education in Portugal. URL: https://dados.gov.pt/pt/reuses/indicadores-gerais-da-educacao/ allowing the elaboration of governmental studies (e.g., Academic Outcomes - Success and Equity - Primary and Secondary Education, URL: https://www.dge.mec.pt/noticias/resultados-escolares-sucesso-e-equidade-ensino-basico-e-secundario and National Exams - Key Indicators, URL: https://www.dge.mec.pt/noticias/exames-nacionais-principais-indicadores-2021) which in turn, facilitate nation-wide media outlets to bring awareness to trends such as: which socio-economic backgrounds in students under- or over-perform across academic curricula (URL: https://www.dnoticias.pt/2022/5/31/313437-alunos-mais-pobres-com-piores-notas-a-exames-como-matematica-e-filosofia/) or which geographies are faster in decreasing the rate of academic failures (URL: https://www.jornaldenegocios.pt/economia/educacao/detalhe/resultados-escolares-ha-cada-vez-menos-chumbos-mas-algarve-e-regiao-de-lisboa-continuam-a-preocupar).
Reviewer 2 Comments: The first two examples seem to be a relevant dataset and not a reuse case. For the third example, please describe the impact created by the project (ie how are the indicators used to achieve some result?).

Justification:
[Response to reviewer]
1- On the environmental challenges of achieving more environmental-friendly cities  and increasing the use of renewable sources of energy the following scientific publication provide insights about the ecological footprint in Portuguese cities, namely the annual demand for natural resources and ecological services by the city's residents and compares it against the “carrying capacity” of the city's ecological assets (URL:https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0264275119302306#s0065) calculated from open datasets such as the ecological footprint and biocapacity open dataset - NGO Global Footprint Network (https://data.footprintnetwork.org/#/). 
2- On the environmental challenge of fighting climate change and connected disasters the following scientific publications provide:
2.1. quantitative insight on the current rate of water depletion under climate change
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0048969720329946 calculated from open datasets such as the EURO-CORDEX iniciative (https://www.euro-cordex.net/060378/index.php.en).
2.2 wildfire proneness under (severe) draught periods https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0048969719323393) calculated from open ERA-Interim datasets (the Copernicus Climate Change service predecessor) https://www.ecmwf.int/en/forecasts/dataset/ecmwf-reanalysis-interim
Reviewer 1 Comments: Please further clarify which data has been used and how these studies/data relate to the impact of open data on environmental challenges

Reviewer 2 Comments:
Viewing the URLs these seem like good projects. However it is not always clear from the descriptions provided here what the projects involve, how open data was used or the impact.
For example 1: how are the models used/what is the impact?
For example 3: what is the app for?

Justification:
1- Predictive model of micro mobility. Besides the predicted commute pattern, the model results will be also useful for micro mobility vehicles operation, improving effectiveness. URL:https://urbandatalab.pt/index.php/component/sppagebuilder/?view=page&id=116 
2- Identification of patterns/profiles and solid waste production prediction. Creation of a service to predict solid waste production a day before, to optimize waste collection in Lisbon. URL:https://urbandatalab.pt/index.php/component/sppagebuilder/?view=page&id=117
3- Environmental impact of municipal trees in public space (including the analysis of levels of carbon sequestered, removal of pollutants and levels of rainwater runoff avoided). URLs: https://dados.gov.pt/pt/datasets/projeto-itree-contribuicao-ambiental-das-arvores-em-espaco-publico/; https://ambiente.cascais.pt/pt/projetos/itree-arvores-das-ruas-cascais
Examples 1 and 2 are outputs of the EU project UCD Lab (Grant Agreement - INES / CEF / ICT / A2018 / 1837945, Action 2018 - EU - IA – 0099), in which AMA is a partner, several applications with open data were developed for the efficiency and effectiveness improvement of public services at the municipality level. Example 3 is an iniciative of CascaisData, the open data platform of the local administration of the municipality of Cascais.

[Response to reviewer]
Examples are:
1- Scientific publications on the topic of water scarcity  provide numbers on the current rate of water depletion under climate change and wildfire proneness under (severe) draught periods (URLs: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0048969720329946 ; https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0048969719323393). This publications raise awareness of the climate change impact on the water scarcity, promoting the adoption of different behaviors)
2- Drought Severity Index. URL: https://www.ipma.pt/en/oclima/observatorio.secas/. This index promotes de awareness of drought severity across regions in Portugal and time, which leads to behabvior change, having an impact on the fight against climate change. 
3- Risk assessment of connected disasters URL: http://www.pnrrc.pt/index.php/geo/. This map promotes the adoption of self-protection behaviors in the face of potential risks of natural, technological or mixed origin (response reviewer)
Reviewer 2 Comments: Please describe the impact of these examples

Justification:
[Response to reviewer]
1- MOBI.E is a public company that has acted, since 2015, as the Managing Entity of the Electric Mobility Network, taking responsibility for the management and monitoring of the network of electric charging stations, particularly in terms of energy, information and financial flows. MOBI.E plays a driving and facilitating role in the process of transition to electric mobility in Portugal, acting as the public instrument for the development of sustainable mobility. "Rede MOBI" is an interactive map allowing to find nearest chargers for EV's https://www.mobie.pt/pt/redemobie/encontrar-posto.  It is possible to track the yearly impact created by the use of the iniciative's services through metrics such as the number of tons of CO2 emissions saved https://www.mobie.pt/pt/redemobie.
2- E-REDES maitains a portal for free access and sharing of data from the energy distribution network throughout the country, with the aim of promoting the country's energy transition and enabling the possibility of developing smart cities projects https://e-redes.opendatasoft.com/pages/homepage/. The data shared can help players in the energy transition in a number of ways, by enabling greater efficiency in the efforts associated with this change. The website provides dataviewers and interactive maps such as the "Number of active energy contracts by meter type" https://e-redes.opendatasoft.com/explore/dataset/21-contadores-de-energia/dashboard/ which allows to track the real-time impact in percentage of smart meters installed.
3- Lisbon Solar Potential MAP - Map which allows to identify the solar potential for all the buildings in Lisbon. URL: https://dados.cm-lisboa.pt/dataset?organization=lisboa-e-nova&tags=Renewable+Energy and also available at URL: https://dados.gov.pt/pt/datasets/carta-de-potencial-solar-de-lisboa/#_. This map is the source data for the SOLIS project - Solar Potential in Lisbon, in the framework of Lisboa Cidade Solar, Lisbon's strategy for solar photovoltaic energy that integrated the Sustainable Energy and Climate Action Plan, approved by the municipality in June 2018. This platform was the start of a work for the promotion of a wide acceptance of solar technology among the citizen. The Platform provided:- three different maps, with the possibility of three territorial display levels - the city, the parish and the building; URL: https://www.solis-lisboa.pt/
Reviewer 2 Comments: The first two examples seem to be portals that make data accessible for reuse. But these are not reuse cases. Are there examples of how the portal has been used in some project and the effect of the reuse?

Justification:
[Response to Reviewer] 
The study, titled "Value Creation through the Reuse of Open Data: Architecture and Implementation of a Serverless Platform in AWS Cloud, Targeting Online Food Retail," aims to quantify the economic impact of reusing open data in the online food retail sector through comprehensive exploration of market data. It emphasizes the development of business insights through advanced analytics within the online retail landscape in Portugal (URL: https://run.unl.pt/handle/10362/149576).
Reviewer 1 Comments: These examples seem to be reuse cases that better fit Q56-Q58. This question is interested in data/studies on the economic impact created by open data.

Justification:
It is possible to infer that the use of open data has impact on employment, since there are new several projects appearing every day that use open data. Those projects require technical and specialized empoyment. Some examples are: 
1- The PORDATA portal that embodies the collection, compilation, systematization and dissemination of open data on multiple areas of society; URL: https://www.pordata.pt/en/home 
2- A study by the New IMS University and the Automobile Club of Portugal, which is in its first phase, analyzes the impact of bicycle paths on mobility in the cities of Lisbon and Porto. This sudy is based on open data from the minicipalities about the bicicle paths. URL: https://www.acp.pt/o-clube/revista-acp/noticias-do-clube/detalhe/impacto-das-ciclovias-na-mobilidade
3- the SOLIS project, Solar Potential in Lisbon, is a platform for the promotion of a wide acceptance of solar technology among the citizen. The Platform provided:- three different maps, with the possibility of three territorial display levels - the city, the parish and the building; and is based on open data on solar irradiation. URL: https://www.solis-lisboa.pt/
Reviewer 2 Comments: Example 2 appears to be a suitable reuse case

Justification:
1- Examples of businesses creation and its products through the re-use of open data can be foud at URL: https://lisboaaberta.cm-lisboa.pt/index.php/pt/apps-e-analitica/apps
2- Portal da Inovação presents information about the entities of NIS (National Innovation System) search investigator's specific skills, entities that work with specific technologies, find business partners, among many functionalities. Several data about Innovation and R&D Entities can be found at https://www.portaldainovacao.pt/Portal_Inovacao/Search.aspx?MobileSearchViewId=1 
3- GovWise is a Data Science company, with professionals in GovTech, and aims to generate value savings, profitability, and return on investment for Public Organizations and Companies that work with the State. It uses open data about public public tendering. URL: https://govwise.ai/

[Response to reviewer] 
1- Some examples include the Travel BI online platform, from the Tourism of Portugal,  an online platform where several data, statistics, graphics and studies regarding the Portuguese tourism are made available to the public. Impact is created by independently monitoring and promoting sustainable tourism practices, facilitating informed decision-making, and fostering regional development and sustainability, both environmental and socio-economic. - URL: https://travelbi.turismodeportugal.pt/sustentabilidade/observatorios-regionais-de-sustentabilidade/
2- Examples of business creation and its products through the re-use of open data. URL: https://lisboaaberta.cm-lisboa.pt/index.php/pt/apps-e-analitica/apps namely:
2.1- https://www.visor.ai/ an AI platform for non-technical customer service teams
2.2 https://load.digital/digital-product-development a web design and UX solutions company in several sectors including medical devices, construction and mobility. 
2.3 https://360waste.pt/ a waste management platform created by https://www.evox.pt/
Reviewer 1 Comments: Please specify how this creates impact
Reviewer 2 Comments: Or give some specific reuse cases from the second example

Develop a governance structure, implement an Open data National Strategy, make data inventories/catalogs (that include information about data, data that cannot be opened, and data that can be opened and is not yet published), send a survey to the entities on data maturity (to each of the government agencies and the departments within), create awareness initiatives (webinar on open data concept and benefits, and the open data directive), and make a portal improvement. Also define methodologies to monitor/evaluate the impact of open data in areas such as government efficiency / public policies; reduction of operating costs; quality of public service provided; environmental impact; social impact; macroeconomic and microeconomic impact, etc. Design a user satisfaction survey.
Public sector data providers still demonstrate some reluctance, there is some cultural tightness, low awareness and data literacy, some departments have limited technological and human resources, and, most basilary, the lack of a general governance structure, in Portugal.

Answer: yes, or all public sector data providers already publish data

In the administration area, login access exclusive, users or providers can check metadata update, data update, followers, visualizations, use cases uploaded to the national portal referencing their data, any problems with the data (for example ...), and any discussion regarding some dataset published by them. 
Files attached "dashborad dataset example.pdf" shows an example for the a specific dataset, on the right side are visible the quality comments. On the top the visualizations.  On the bottom other parameters and infos, like followers, community resources and comments.
Files attached "dashborad provider example.pdf" shows an example for a provider. On the top are visible the visualizations and followers. Other infos are visible, like different status indicators for each dataset, providers' followers and community comments.

[Response to reviewer] Further explanation: 
There are 3 main forms for dataset registry, the following 2 are an approach to keep up-to date the metada: via portal API, whera data and metada is updated; and Harvesting.
The manual approach registry should be used for non dynamic data, but such is not controlled by us.

For part of the HVD, namely those in the Geospatial, Earth Obs. and Meteorological categories and already following the INSPIRE directive (and providing the addition of specific HVD metadata, in presente development) the interoperbility is going to be provided.

[Response to reviewer] Further explanation: 
In particular part of the HVD, namely those in the Geospatial, Earth Obs. and Meteorological categories, that are already following the INSPIRE directive, the interoperbility is already ensured in the international context. For the remaining type of datasets there is not yet a pre-defined approach to ensure that interoperability, and it relies only on the metadata quality.

In the administration area, the user can access the published datasets. For each dataset, there is a "quality" box. That box aims to help the user improve the quality of the (meta)data associated with that dataset. It gives an overview of what will be useful for contributors to find and reuse that data. Publishing a dataset involves filling in several fields. The system analyzes whether this filling was done correctly. From there comes information about the quality of the dataset - it can suggest a more accurate and detailed description, the use of more tags, or the attachment of resources in a more open and machine-readable format. See attachment "111.a"

Each dataset in a metadata quality rating.

[Response to reviewer] Further explanation: 
For all datasets in dados.gov there is a built-in tool in the udata (6.0.2) framework that informs the user about the metada quality. This information is given by a dropdown window, below the dataset title on to the " [ i ] Qualidade dos metadados" (ENG: Metadata quality)

See Example: https://dados.gov.pt/pt/datasets/justica-no-mapa/
